video.title: Arduino Course for Beginners - Open-Source Electronics Platform
video.description:
Learn how to use Arduino hardware and software in this full course for beginners. Arduino is an easy-to-use, open-source electronics platform. Arduino boards are able to read inputs - light on a sensor, a finger on a button, or a Twitter message - and turn it into an output - activating a motor, turning on an LED, publishing something online. You can tell your board what to do by sending a set of instructions to the microcontroller on the board.

No hardware is required for to follow along with this course!

✏️ Course developed by Ashish Bansal.
📸 Ashish on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ashish_things/

Tinker with the circuits used in the course : 
🔗 custom blink function: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ib4c08HDTAe
🔗 digitalRead & digitalWrite : https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bvTdKaqDvQc
🔗 analogRead :  https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6kEEQR3GZC1
🔗 analogWrite :  https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hDwWdu92kws

topLevelComment.author: Ashish Bansal
topLevelComment.text:
I hope that this course helps people who are just starting their journey with Arduino or have some brilliant project ideas in their mind but are clueless about how to program an Arduino. This course will begin with the basic electronics concepts and then gradually teach about Arduino Programming. Arduino's programming language is derived from C++, so this course will also cover essential C++ concepts. 

During my time working with Arduino, I have seen many people building great projects and product prototypes using this piece of hardware. Artists, designers, and even chefs who had absolutely no idea about electronics, sensors, and programming coupled their creativity with electronics and came up with fantastic work. 

So this course is also an attempt to encourage people, regardless of their background, to start building stuff that they have in their mind without thinking that they don't know enough to begin. 

Certainly, this course is not the end to the world of Arduino. For making some projects, one may need to know advanced concepts such as EEPROM, interrupts, communication buses like SPI, I2C, etc. But before moving to that, one needs to familiarize themselves with the basics.

I look forward to seeing the projects people come up with after finishing this course.

topLevelComment.text: can anyone let me know why is a resistor necessary for 3:41:30? thanks

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text: If you don't use the resistor, you would be shorting the positive and negative terminals while pressing the switch. That would lead to lot of heat generation in the wire. Which is not a good thing. If arduino detects a short, it turns itself off. That's why we connect resistance. And while the switch is not pressed, the pin is connected to ground through a resistance and that would prevent it from reading floating values.

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
Yes you can think of them as power supplies in this case. But the current output is very limited. The main Microcontroller controls these pins based on the logic you write in the code. 
The main power supplies are 3.3v and 5v. These have a slightly higher current output capacity. 
You can check the technical specifications to know the exact current capacity of each pin. 

For arduino Uno, I have explained this in technical specifications section.

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
If your port and board is selected properly, then it is likely that your board is faulty. 
You can troubleshoot by checking if your port is correct then the type of board is correctly selected. 
Then you can try to change your USB cable once.
If it still doesn't work, try with a different arduino.

topLevelComment.author: Firmly Wahlang
topLevelComment.text: Hello sir what is serial.begin (9600) mean??

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text: This is a command to start the serial communication between Arduino and Computer USB at the baud rate of 9600 bits per second. This value can be changed to a different number based on the data transfer needs. Typically, 9600 bps is enough for printing data on serial monitor.

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
I don't think that you can upload more than 1 program. However, in a single program, you can write your multiple programs and switch that using a button maybe. 

For example , 
If button1 is pressed {
Run program1
}

.
.
.
.
If button_n is pressed {
Run program_n
} 

You may have to set flags for momentary switches or you can use lockable push button switch in order to preserve button state. 

In this manner you can decide which program to run.

topLevelComment.author: tupac1971ful
topLevelComment.text:
2:40:57 What i dont get is that the first loop when is run, itstarts at int=0 and then its incremented +1 so on the next loop will start at 1.
But, why does the second loop "int j = 0" will always starts from 0 after each of the first "int i" loop and not from where it had left?

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text: @tupac1971ful you're welcome 😀

replies.author: tupac1971ful
replies.text: @Ashish Bansal that made things clear! Thank you very much for the explanation

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
Hi,
Always remember that the code will always do what you tell it to. 
In this case, see the loop with i as outer loop and the loop with j as inner loop. 
Both the loops are starting from zero.

The flow is like this : 
The flow enters into the outer loop and then into the inner loop. While the inner loop is running, the j variable is incrementing and nothing is happening to Variable i. Once the inner loop has finished executing, then the i Variable will increment by one and then again the flow will go into inner loop. And it will be reinitialised by 0 because it will be a fresh run for the inner loop as the previous run was over. But the outer loop is still going on. And it will go on till the condition specified becomes false. 

For each iteration of outer loop, a complete inner loop will run. 

I hope it cleared your doubt.

topLevelComment.author: Saravanan Subni
topLevelComment.text: Hi, In Switch case, after  break removed  then how the case statement executed continuously without getting the value of case is true? then what is the need to check each case value

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
That's how it is designed to work. 
If you only want one case to be executed, then you must use break. 

To answer the second part of your question :
Let's say you are programing for a situation where you're checking something in a particular order. And you have written your case statements in that order. And now you want , while checking in order,  if something gets true, you have to execute rest of the statements no matter what. So in that case, you don't need to check any condition. So in this scenario you can write your case statements without break and it should solve your purpose.

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
The resistance in series with the led is to prevent the led from getting damaged due to high current. 

The resistance in series with the switch is needed to read the voltage drop accross it. If you don't use resistance, you'll get floating values. 

Floating values means random high or low.

topLevelComment.author: Arweinydd Rhyfel
topLevelComment.text:
Please someone explain this to me 🙏🙏🙏

In the 2nd example at 59:40, current always flows from positive to negative, right?! So by placing the LED first and then the resistor, won't the LED get fried?! Isn't it the resistor that is supposed to reduce the current flow of the circuit before it crosses the LED?!

replies.author: Arweinydd Rhyfel
Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
Resistor + LED form a series circuit. In a series circuit, the current is same throughout. So it doesn't matter if you place the resistance first or the led. 

To answer your doubt, the current doesn't start out of the battery like you are thinking. That it will lower down if it finds a resistance. The current that comes out of battery depends on the total equivalent resistance of the circuit. So it doesn't matter on the position of resistance or LED. The equivalent resistance would still be the same.

I would recommend that you watch the portion where I have explained resistance in series and parallel.

topLevelComment.author: ALL IN ALL NO.1
topLevelComment.text:
Bro I need to run 16 gear motor using esp8266 

For that what driver I should use

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
And to answer how to connect 4 motor drivers, it really depends on the kind of motor driver you're using and how many pins it needs. It should not exceed the number of pins available on esp8266. You may use some shift register or multiplexers to use one pin as more than one pin, but that may complicate your project. 

So you'll have to see what works best for you.

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
@ALL IN ALL NO.1  most of the motor drivers work on a set pattern. They have two control pins. If you give 0 (low) state to both the pins, the connected motors stays off. If you give 1 (high) state to both of them, then also, the connected motor stays off. If you give high state to one pin and low state to other pin, the motor starts moving. Let's say it's moving clockwise with respect to you. Now if you reverse the state of pins, the motor will move anti clockwise with respect to you. 

Some other motor drivers may have an additional enable pin which you need to set high. 

So if you understand the specification of the  motor driver you are using, you can set the desired logic to those pins using your esp8266. 

Also note that you may need to use a level shifter as some motor drivers may not consider 3.3V as high state.

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text:
After connecting the board check if it is shown in device manager as Arduino at COM X. Where X is some number. 
If not, unplug it, and see if anything disappears from the device manager list. 

If that's the case, chances are that your board is using a cheap USB to Serial Convertor. 

In that case, you'll have to install CH340 driver. 
Link : https://cdn.sparkfun.com/assets/learn_tutorials/8/4/4/CH341SER.EXE


This is by sparkfun, and you can also checkout their tutorial for the same. 


If it doesn't work, there is something wrong with the hardware you are using. Maybe the Arduino board, the cable, or the USB port of your PC.

Can u please tell me what is serial monitor

replies.author: Henry
replies.text:
The UART hardware of the ATMega328p AVR Chip of your Arduino can communicate through a serial to USB converter chip to your PC. The serial monitor in the Arduino IDE is a program that can connect to the com port to show the text your arduino sketch outputs through the UART TX pin with Serial.print()
you can also send serial data back to the UART RX pin if you have an arduino sketch that tries to read serial data

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text: You can think of it as a white board where Arduino can print all the communication taking place between computer and Arduino through USB in a human readable form. It can be used to see the variables which are there in the Arduino memory. We can also use it to debug our program. Bcz a debugger is presently not available in the stable version of Arduino IDE. It is present in beta version.

topLevelComment.author: Fling Monkey
topLevelComment.text: I have been a test automation engineer for over 30 years. I have no degree, but that has not stopped me from programming PC-based test systems for both verification and functional testing. I am totally self-taught on-the-job. A few years ago I was forced to start using an Arduino for a project, and WOW, my eyes were opened. With the Arduino I can access hundreds (if not thousands) of sensors and actuators and controllers and I can access the real world without purchasing expensive test equipment from National Instruments or other vendors. I don't think I would want to be an Arduino-only engineer, but being able to use the Arduino has been a fantastic skill to add to my skill set. Recently I have started fabricating Arduino-based PCBs through EasyEDA, and that has again expanded my reach. Now I can make robust test fixtures without having a ball of wires. I recently landed a new job and, after I had been there a short time, my boss said they had no idea what they were getting when they hired me, I exceeded all expectations and surprised them with my solutions. Arduino is a key factor in that. It is both a job and a hobby, and it is sometimes hard to tell where one leaves off and the other picks up.

topLevelComment.author: SpinStar1956
topLevelComment.text:
BREADBOARD FACE-PALM: The reason it got the name breadboard was mainly from very-early Amateur Radio (Ham-Radio).  
Bread used to be stored in a dedicated wooden box (this is before plastic-bags were invented).  Many of these had a cutting-board that would slide out (often with the loaf of bread already sitting on it, ready to be cut (also before sliced-bread was common; most people baked their own bread). Once you sliced your bread, you slid the cutting-board back in and then the breadbox could be closed tightly to keep the bread fresh. 
So, it is really the cutting-board inside the breadbox that was named 'bread-board.'  And since most ham/radio/electricity experimenters did not have metal working equipment, most all projects were mounted open on a wooden-board; hence breadboard!   73...

topLevelComment.author: Monke
topLevelComment.text:
Please help me, I can't understand the nested for loop used for the stars..
if j executes once and becomes 0 again then why doesn't i become 0 too?

replies.author: Ashish Bansal
replies.text: Consider the loop with 'i' as an outer loop and the one with 'j' as inner loop. The code flow starts from the outer loop and then goes into the inner loop. The inner loop ends as soon as the condition "j<=i' becomes false. When the inner loop ends, we have asked the compiler to print a new line. after that,  'i' is incremented and the condition for outer loop is still true. Hence 'i' doesn't become 0.
